page.title: 06WOODWICK
page.content: Before 1066 a monk held Woodwick, then from 1066 onwards a man called Ranulf Flambard held it.Woodwick paid tax for 300 acres,which is land for three ploughs.They shared half a mill with Freshford which paid 5s.They had twelve acres of meadow and 30 acres of pasture.The value was 20s.After many years people moved to Freshford because it was too small to support a rector. When the people left Woodwick the village slowly crumbled down and grass started to grow over the top of the village.Now all you can see are humps and bumps where cottages used to be.Also now a road has been built over the top of the village and a few houses as well.Now the fields are used for grazing cattle.
